doc.field: New York City Arts Community COVID-19 Response Web Collection
New York City Arts Community COVID-19 Response Web Collection

Anarcha, Lucey, Betsey is an audiovisual journey through the history of gynecology, presented as a website that includes collage, imagery, video, and a manifesto. The artist, Klau Kinky, learned of the harrowing stories of Anarcha, Lucy, Betsey, and other women experimented on during what Harriet A. Washington calls Medical Apartheid while researching ejaculation glands. Through the microsite, Kinky traces and connects the use of enslaved bodies by gynecologists and anatomists to tools and their histories in medical experimentation, the birth of urogynecology and its ramifications on the rhetoric of the prostate, female ejaculation, surgery for incontinence and vaginoplasty cosmetics, and current practices of welfare urogynecology in Africa, offering a radical proposal for body decolonization by honoring bodies brutalized in the name of "research."
